content: Increased average fuel economy standards. Increased average fuel economy standards are amended in section 32902 of title 49, United States Code to include non-passenger automobiles and classes based on vehicle attributes related to fuel economy. The amendment includes setting average fuel economy standards for non-passenger automobiles based on vehicle attributes related to fuel economy, with a minimum standard of 27.5 miles per gallon for model year 2022 and subsequent years. The Secretary must prescribe standards for passenger automobiles at least 18 months before each model year. The Secretary must set average fuel economy standards for passenger automobiles at least 18 months before each model year, with a maximum feasible level determined for manufacturers to achieve. Separate standards may be prescribed for different classes of passenger automobiles based on fuel economy-related vehicle attributes. The Secretary sets average fuel economy standards for passenger automobiles, with separate standards for different classes based on vehicle attributes. The standard for model year 2022 and beyond must be at least 35 miles per gallon. Alternative minimum standards may also be set for passenger automobiles. The average fuel economy standard for model year 2022 and subsequent years must be a minimum of 35 miles per gallon. Alternative minimum standards may apply to domestically manufactured passenger automobiles. The fuel economy standard for passenger automobiles must be a minimum of 35 miles per gallon for model year 2022 and beyond. Additionally, an alternative minimum standard applies to domestically manufactured passenger automobiles, set at either 27.5 miles per gallon or 92 percent of the average fuel economy projected by the Secretary for all manufacturers in that model year. The Secretary will project the average fuel economy for all manufacturers' vehicles in a model year, to be published in the Federal Register. The alternative minimum standard applies to domestically manufactured passenger automobiles based on vehicle attributes, excluding any credits transferred from other categories of automobiles. The Secretary will provide a transition period for manufacturers to comply with the average fuel economy standard for passenger automobiles based on vehicle attributes. The Secretary will provide a transition period for manufacturers to comply with standards for passenger automobiles based on vehicle attributes, with an option to comply with a single corporate average fuel economy level. The amendments made by this section will take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act. The amendments made by this section will take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act, with a transition period for passenger automobiles to comply with existing standards until new standards are prescribed. Section 32902(b) of title 49, United States Code, remains in effect until new standards for passenger automobiles are established. Chapter 329 of title 49 is amended to include a definition of "non-passenger automobile." Section 32902 of title 49, United States Code is amended to include a definition of "non-passenger automobile" and expand the subsections to include (a), (b), (c), or (d) for compliance. Section 32902 of title 49, United States Code is amended to include subsections (a), (b), (c), or (d) for compliance. Subsections (h) and (j) are also updated accordingly. Section 32903 is revised by striking certain subsections. In section 32903, amendments include striking certain subsections and updating subsections (a) through (d) of section 32902 for compliance. Subsection (e) now refers to "non-passenger automobiles." Amendments include updating subsections in section 32902 for compliance, specifically referring to "non-passenger automobiles." Additionally, section 32909(b) is revised by removing certain language related to petitions for review. SEC. 2. Credit transferring within a manufacturer's fleet. The Secretary of Transportation will establish a credit transferring program for manufacturers to transfer fuel economy credits within their fleet to comply with standards. The Secretary of Transportation will establish a credit transferring program for manufacturers to transfer fuel economy credits within their fleet to comply with standards. Credits transferred can be used in the same model years and the maximum increase in any compliance category is 1.0 mile per gallon. Transfers of credits to certain automobile categories are limited. The maximum increase in any compliance category due to transferred credits is 1.0 mile per gallon. Transfers of credits to certain automobile categories are limited to comply with fuel economy standards. Credits can only be transferred if earned in model year 2010 or later. In model year 2010 or later, credits can be transferred between compliance categories of automobiles, limited to a maximum increase of 1.0 mile per gallon. The term 'fleet' refers to all automobiles manufactured by a manufacturer in a specific model year. The term 'compliance category of automobiles' refers to 3 categories: passenger automobiles manufactured domestically, passenger automobiles not manufactured domestically, and non-passenger automobiles.
